Name: Tanagra Statuette of a Girl Playing Harp
Description: The terra-cotta statuette depicts a girl holding a triangular lute, lyre, or harp. She is standing on a base with her left leg to the front and a little bit bent. She wears a long dress with pleats and a cloth belt and she carries the harp behind her shoulder. Her face is full and round. She wears heavy earrings and a complicated and high hairstyle. The statuette has a hole in the back and has traces of crimson color. The portrayal of the girl musician appeared in the group of Tanagra figurines found in the necropolis of Alexandria. The Tanagra figurines are distinguished by a diversity of shapes. They generally portray women. They were named after a small town named Tanagra in Boeotia, Greece, where many similar statues were found.
